Introduction

The menstrual cycle involves a complex interplay of hormones controlled by the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (HPO) axis to regulate the ovary and uterine endometrium.  The menstrual cycle is approximately 28 days in length and consists of 2 main phases—follicular and luteal—separated by ovulation.

Hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis



The HPO axis is the central regulatory system of the menstrual cycle and consists of the following components (

figure 1
):



  • Hypothalamus:  Releases pulsatile gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which stimulates the anterior pituitary gland.
  • Anterior pituitary gland:  Releases gonadotropins (follicle-stimulating hormone [FSH], luteinizing hormone [LH]) in response to GnRH.
  • Ovary:  Responds to FSH by initiating follicular development, which produces estradiol through follicular steroidogenesis.

Follicular phase (days 1-14)



The follicular phase begins on the first day of menstruation (

figure 2
).  The primary objectives of the follicular phase are to create a dominant follicle (ie, ovarian follicular phase) and a thickened endometrium (ie, endometrial proliferative phase) conducive to embryo implantation.  Therefore, the ovarian follicular phase, which is estrogen driven, directly corresponds to the endometrial proliferative phase.



During the follicular phase:



  • FSH levels are initially high (in response to pulsatile GnRH release from the hypothalamus) while LH levels are initially low.  Estrogen and progesterone levels are at their lowest points within the menstrual cycle.
  • Within the ovary, FSH recruits a cohort of primary follicles that, with maturation, secrete estradiol through steroid synthesis in the surrounding theca and granulosa cells (
    figure 3
    ).  A dominant follicle is selected by day 7 of the menstrual cycle and begins to grow rapidly while the other follicles undergo apoptosis.
  • Rising estradiol levels drive endometrial mitosis, proliferation, and stromal vascularization (
    image 1
    ), resulting in a thickened proliferative endometrium.
  • Estradiol exerts negative feedback on the hypothalamus and pituitary gland to inhibit further FSH release, thereby preventing the continual recruitment of follicles.

Ovulation (day 14)



Ovulation marks the midpoint of the cycle, or the transition between the follicular and luteal phases.  At the midpoint of the cycle, rising estradiol levels cause a unique neuroendocrine phenomenon in which negative feedback changes to positive feedback, resulting in the LH surge.  This surge triggers ovulation, or the release of one mature oocyte from the dominant follicle within the ovary.

Luteal phase (days 15-28)



Following ovulation, the luteal phase begins, and FSH and LH levels rapidly decline.  Within the ovary, the follicular remnant luteinizes and begins to secrete increasing levels of progesterone.  At the endometrium, the rising progesterone levels induce secretory endometrial changes, which include spiral vessel coiling and large intracytoplasmic glycogen vacuole deposition within the endometrial cells.  Therefore, the ovarian luteal phase (which is progesterone driven) directly corresponds to the endometrial secretory phase (

image 2
).



If an embryo implants within the endometrium, β-hCG is secreted and sustains the corpus luteum.  Without this pregnancy hormone, the corpus luteum degrades, progesterone declines, and the endometrium sheds.  As progesterone levels fall, FSH levels gradually rise to begin the cycle again.



In women with normal, ovulatory menstrual cycles, the luteal phase is consistently 14 days in length.  Any variations in cycle length occur due to variability of the length of the follicular phase.



Summary



The normal menstrual cycle is a dynamic and finely regulated process involving intricate histologic changes within the ovaries and endometrium.  The balance of hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian hormones coordinates these events through complex feedback loops to produce one mature oocyte and an endometrium conducive to implantation.
